pageContext.desc: Legal and financial documents of an 18th-century Connecticut businessman and Continental Army purchasing agent.

Chauncey Whittelsey Esq. To Charles Miller Dr.
1781

Recd Middletown of Jany 5th 1781 of Mr Chauncey Whittelsey a Discharge of all Clothg Acct in full against the town of Wallingford in Confederation of my having Pd him Two Pounds Eighteen Shillings State money David Hall Selectman

[unclear] Town of Wallingford

              David Hall
              Jany 5th 1781
              Entered

Newlundon Janu unclearth 1785
Mr. Chuncy Whittlecey unclear to John Humphrey to freight of 135 Booshels Salt  at 4 unclear Booshel
Pounds 13-10-0

John Humphry
Bill [unclear]
Jany 1781

Newlondon January.12.1781
(eg.,Sir) 
(ie.,"unclear") (eg.,Capt.) Naterman we (eg.,req) One Hundred
& thirteen Bushells Salt, of by Cap. (eg.,n) John Humphrey
Seven Hundred & thirty five Bushels Salt as
measured when Taken into our (ie.,"unclear")
youl observe if falls short in (eg.,Measuring) over
again, from what they received it at.
Enclosed is (eg.,Capt.) Humphreys (ie.,"unclear")
which he requested us to forward to you
in order that you might lend him
the Money here again if he returns here
(ie.,"unclear") in (eg.,four) Days (ie.,"unclear) we gave Receipts
for no more Salt than is measured when
we took it in

        we are (eg.,"Sir")
                    your Most (ie.,"unclear")
                           Edward Hallam (eg.,"Of")

Chauncy Whittelsey Esq

                    Middletown

Recd. Middletown Jany 12th 1781 of Chauncy Whittlesey twelve Lord Dollars for freight of four half Chests Tea & three Mats Duck from Bedford to Middletown

Providence January 13 1781

[Sir?]
I have sent [VM In?] Humphrey Seven hundred & Fifty five Bushels of the salt belong to [you?] [Unclear] of [Conui-] left in my care by you.  The following on a [Duplicate?] of the [Unclear].  [Rue? of [VM?] Samuel Hamlin of Providence Seven hundred & Fifty five Bushels of salt belonging to [you?] [Unclear] of [Conn-unclear] which I promise to [DO to] Chauncy Whittlesey [Laf] a Middletown or in his [absence?] to [VM?] for *King, should the river be shut to [Mr.?] Edward Hollom of NeW London for [Eintomery freyht?] Danger of [y Jean & ?????] excepted.  [Sing m?] Humphrey
I have sent [Symbol] Cap Waterman one hundred and & [blotted out] Twenty Bushels of W [lulon?] to you [care?] of [Indescipherable, Commonwealth?] the same direction as was given to M. Humphry and on [the] same [town?]
I am your most [indescipherable] [Name]
B [Post Script?]  [????] thank you to [mention?] to W G [Meap?] that I have sent the 2 bags of wool he left in my care [Scribbling?] Waterman

Sam Hamlins

Middletown 31st Jan'ry 1781
Sir
pay, or discount W. Lamberton Cooper twenty pounds State money, and take up a Note he has against my Brother George & you'l oblige yours
John Willy
Chancy Whlttelsy Esq?
Middletown

John Weller;
order
January 31st 1781


(eg.,"Sam") Cooper

Salem (eg.,(1) Feb. of 1781

Sir

           your (ie.,uncertain) of (ie.,abbreviation unknown) came safe to 

hand. Inclosing the find of two (ie.,uncertain) Bills Prechange
upon (eg.,Treasurer) at (ie.,uncertain) for Eight thousand five hundred
& Fifty (ie.,uncertain)), the Small Balance is so Trifeling,
I beg you will not Trouble yourself to (eg.,end)
(eg., Consider your note as paid, was crossed out), I have Inclosed the Bills
upon the note of (ie.,uncertain) if fully Paid & will send it 
At the first opportunity, you will Please to Receive
of Mr. Clay the Money for the shore (ie.,uncertain) (ie.,uncertain) which
(ie.,uncertain) I feal myself under particular obligation
for your attention in sending me the Bills (ie.,uncertain)
be happy in keeping up a Correspondence with you
& if I can be of any Service in Transacting Briefing
here for you it will aford me Pleasure, our Friend
(eg.,C.wh.) Clay has safe and once more in the W. Indies
I make no doubt he will make a good hand of it
this winter, below you have Some (ie., uncertain) of W. India
goods perhaps it may be of Some Advantage

                                                 I Am
                                                 Sir with Respect
                                                 yr. Most Ob. friend
                                                 (ie.,Name Uncertain)

Salt (Uncertain of Rest)
W.I. Rum 20 Pound - (ie.,uncertain)
(ie.,uncertain) - 13.10 —

Cotton — 13 (abbreviation unknown)
Mr. Chauncey Whittlesley

1781

to Freight of 122 Booshell of Solt
from Provenence to Newlundon

New London Feby.8.1781

Sir,
have received an Addition of Salt 
from WM Humphry of One Hundred
& twenty two bushels — for the
State of Connecticut — WM
Humphry, Requests you to lend
the Freight to our care that I may
lend it him

                          (uncertain of phrasing)
                          Edward Hallam (eg., H. or M. ?)


Chauncy Whittlesey Esqr

Ed Hallam's
Letter & Rect
Feby 8th 1781

Boston Feby 8. 1781

Sir
your favor of (ie.,abbreviation uncertain). Instead Inclosing a Bill of Exchange, have (ie.,uncertain) of Notes (ie.,uncertain) I wrote you the 18th (?) the Receipt of which you do not Acknowledge. The Bill you have sent me is so Large that it will be difficult Selling it, at least it will not sell for so much. a Smaller one (ie.,next four words uncertain) and Less or you a proper Voucher of the Sale of the Bills. I am entirely Satisfyed with the Agreement you have made. I Shall begin immediately to Send on The
Rum (ie:uncertain) agreeable to your (eg.,[Request]]) & if your money does not come in Season, shall do the best I can for your Interests, You (ie.,[uncertain]) on only a part of the Sale to be forwarded. I must request you to let me know by return of the post how much I shall Send on. If The weather holds Good, can have The whole delivered at Providence in 15 days. I know very well how those great (ie.,[uncertain]) Act when they have for a poor fellow to (eg.,torment). any (ie.,[uncertain])

answered, then the (eg.,[Devil]) who the (ie.,(rest of line uncertain)
If you should have any other calls for any kind of Good from this (ie.,[uncertain]. I always Stand to obay your Command

                                                                                                             I am in haste
                                                                                                            Yourmost Obd Ser
                                                                                                             Charles Miller

Once Current
WI Rum   Pounds 21 w 22. /
(uncertain)  Pounds 12.10/
Salt — 43 to 45 without (uncertain)
Sugars 170 to 180  Coffee 50/
Chocolate 7y (uncertain)

Chatham February 20th 1781
To Mr Chauncy Whittlese Sir Pay Hanover and of Jack knifes Twenty Seven Pounds Ten Shillings Hand money on the Discount in Continental or State Bills and I? Will acount the Same With by Way of the Ship Chatham and youl Oblige.
your Humble Servant Chauncy Bulkley

Chy Bulkleys order
Recd. the within order in full
pr Isaac unclear

Sir                                                                               Boston March 1st 1781
Your favor of 14th Ult. came to (ie.,[uncertain]) by Post Last Evening— I have sold the Bill of Exchange at fifty three for one after much Difficulty had I been able to have kept it to this time, it would have sold for much more — Supposing from your letter of (ie.,[Maybe a Date?]) that you wanted all your Rums Salt Forwarded I have been pushing it with all (ie.,[requisition]) have only now about fifteen Goods Remaining on board, which will go on in a Day or Two — But I am much Disappointed in not Receiving a Remittance by this Opportunity as you wrote me in yours of (eg.,[Date?])that you expected in a few Days to be able to Remitt me. Three or four hundred (eg.,proceed), New Continental on the strength of this (ie.,[unknown]) no Doubt that I Should soon be (ie.,[unknown]) what I ask Advanced — I must Therefore Beg you to use y ?
Utmost (eg.,[Endevores]) to Remitt me by Return of Post, as I want Every Farthing of my own Money to purchase Bills, as they are about Rising fast The

The French having Ten Millions of Livres (ie.,[unknown]) in this Harbour, in hard Cash — As soon as I have compleated forwarding the Goods I Shall send you a particular Recount of them — Pray push your great men for Cash — 

                                                                          I am Sir
                                                                             your Most (ie.,[unknown]) Servant.
                                                                             Charles Miller


(Bottom of Letter)
Letter
Charles Miller Esq

[Yhee?] Middletown April 12th [1781?] of unclear [Whittelry?] unclear one hundred fifty three pounds four [shillings?] unclear. Money in full for unclear due to unclear of [Donbury?] on unclear
[Ladark?] Benedict

Recd
Town of Danbury
April 12th 181
[?E?}

Bedford Dartmouth, 13th of Sept.? 1785
Respected Friends 
Whittelsey & Hubbard
By the Gottenburg Capt. Claghorn from Sweden, I have received acct Sales of some Tobacco which I ship'd by hi and consign'd to my Friend Henry Greig of Gottenburg together with a parcel of 13 Casks of yours with 10? Casks of Parsons & Cooly of Springfield.   I have received acct. sales of mine & yours & yours I inclose with that of Parsons & Cooly - together with your acct. with e on that Adventure - which was cosign'd to me with mine - it is a poor price for Tobacco in Europe, but New England Tobacco even of the best quality will not answer at that market, indeed nothing short of best kind of Virginia - and my friend writes me he was very sorry it was so poor - , By your acct you will see what I have for you , and I request your directions therein of which I must do with your Good, by first opportunity, as also directions from Parsons & Cooly, who I beg you will inform hereof - in the mean while remain your Friend 
Caleb Greene

To
Whittlesey & Hubbard
Hartford
or
Middletown
Caleb Green Letter
April 13th 1781
various calculations in margin

Roi? Middleton Ap! 19th 1701 of Chauncey Whittesley sundry? Pay Table Order amounting to one hundred forty five pounds for one ?? sugar to be delivered at Norwich at ten pounds ??, in [??] the order cannot be negotiated to be returned. Sam [Woodridge?] [Pound Symbol] 145

Recd. S. Woodbridge
145£
Apl. 19th 1781

East Windsor May 8th 1781
Sir
I have lately received a letter from you which acquaints me that you have converced with W. Hubbard and other gentlemen concerning the Hatts which I [{sent?]] you and very Sorry that they did not answer your expectation, was I in my power as it is agreeable to you I should pay you to the unclear of what I received for the hatts, but as I have been building? what money I had is spent that way and therefore I must do as I can, I expect you to except of all of these but those made of the coarse wool, which I think you agreed to when I was at your store as to those of the coarse unclear I leave it with your generosity to do the best you can with them, as to the trimmings they are more others of the same kind of which you have even had? of me when there was no fault found with then I unclear it unclear for me to deduct one quarter from the value of these to have them pass? but necessity obliges me to leave them because I am not able to redeem them, I intend the others shall answer your expectation I did never intend the unclear should suffer by me but was deceived by my workemen as I have told you before unclear unclear I yet mean that they shall if it is in my power consistent? with reason to satisfy them. 
I am your Humble Servant
Noah Welles
W. Chauncey Whittelsey
Middletown

Mr Chauncey Whittlesey
Middletown
Noah Welles Letter
May 8th 1781
concerning hatts

Jabez Hamlin Esq Judge of the Court of Probate for the District of Middletown in the State of Connecticutt in New England holding said unclear to unclear Chauncey Whittelsey of said Middletown. Greetings -- whereas the Country Court in and for the County of Hartford on the First? Tuesday of Feby unclear did sentence judge and unclear the Estate Real & Personal of James Jauncey Esq of New York Lying and Being in the State of Connecticutt to unclear forfeit to & for the use of said State of Connecticutt and to unclear used and administered on according to one unclear Statute of said State Entitled an Act for Confiscating the Estates of Persons Inimical to the Independence and Liberties of the united States within this State and for payment of their debts and Divesting Proceeding therein and being Desirous that said estate both Real & Personal should be administered Accrdg to Law. 
I do therefore Investing in your Fidelity & Care Commit unto you the said Chauncey Whittelsey full Power of Administration the Goods, Chattels, Credits & Estate of the said James Jauncey Esq According to Law.  and to pay all Debts, in which he stood Bound in this State so far as his Good, Chattels & Estate can Extend according to the Value thereof and to make a true & perfect Inventory of all and Singular Goods, Chattels, Credits and Estate of the said James Jauncey, and Exhibit the Same into the Registry of the said Court of Probate within Twenty Days, after the date hereof and also render to the said Court a true unclear unclear of your administration within One Year from the Date hereof and I do by these presents? ordain depute + constitute you Administrator of all and Singular the Goods, Chattels & Estate aforesaid in witness whereof I have Caused the Clerk of sd. Court to unclear these presents and fix the seal of said office thereto this 7th day of May AD one 1785?
Sign'd unclear Order. 
unclear Bezaleel Fisk Clerk   Jabez Hamllin

We the subscribers appointed to apprize the half of seventy acres of land late the property of David Cook and deeded by him to James Jauncy and John Smith senior of New York now in the pofestion of Theophilus Merriman. To apprize these half including one quarter of the houfe belonging to Jauncy at 4122 - 10 - 0 lawful money certified in us, Caleb look apprizens Miles Johnson under oath. 
Walliney Ford June 2, 1787

Appraisment
Cook Lot

Bedford in Dartmouth unclear 25.1791

Respected Friend
Chauncey Whittelsey

                                         Agreeable to the direction and order of Whittelsey & Hubbard I have ship'd by the bearer William. Akin four half chests of Tea & three matts Duck as by unclear inclosed I hope the Goods may get safe to hand. I think the Tea is very good. - and as I have Twenty four pounds (good weight) due me out of box w19. and thinking it would damage the box to open it, considering it must be transported, I therefore have let it go with the rest, and must beg the favour of thy delivering it to the bearer. Akin having given him my order therefore, I have also given unclear. Akin the acct. of chargers amounting to unclear. which thou will please to discharge  he having paid me
                                        I am thy Respectful
                                                   & unclear Friend
                                                       Caleb Greene

P.S. I said good weight because by the allowance of Large Fare as Gotteb unclear Tea will overun here

Chauncey Whittelsey

           unclear
            Middletown
            Connecticut.

Rec. of Chaucney Whitteney unclear june 30, [1701?]. Two hundred pounds  for one eighth of the [bag]. Three [sisters?] now [laying?] as Middletown, with all her [appentanance?], unclear Whitteney to be accountable for his [1/8th?] of unclear since [brig?] has been as Middletown. Edward Hallam

For Value recd. I Increase Morely of Woodbury promise to pay unto Chauncey Whittelsey of Middletown, Administrator on the Estate of James Jauncey Esqr. declared forfeit; the Sum of three hundred Pounds Lawful Money in twelve Months from the Date, with Lawful Interest until paid As Witness my hand at Middletown this 13th Day of July AD 1781-

July 13th 1781

We the Subscribers being desired to appraise certain piece of Land in the Town of New Haven that did belong to James Jauncey Decd. that lyes near the dwelling house of Michael Baldwin which contains three Quarters of an acre and four rods, being  Sworn according to Law, having viewed the Land do appraise the Same at the Sum of Forty Pounds Lawfull money
James Gilbert
Joel Gilbert

Hartford Septr. 28th 1781
Sir
Please to deliver the bearer Capt. Ingraham Twenty tlo? Salt - I am Sir yr. Very Hm Sr
Geo. Merrills
Chauncey Whittlesey Esqr
Middletown

Recd. Middletown Spet 29th 1781 of Chy Whittelsey twenty cask? salt containing as pr. Marks? two hundred & fifty four & onhalf Bushels to be delivered to Mr. Geo. Merrils at Nortford also one half Chest of Tea to be delivered the same, on Acct. Messrs Persons & Cooley Springfield, he? paying freight accustomed have signed duplicate Rects
Br John Ingraham
Order G. Merrils
for Salt
Sept. 1781
E

New Haven October 1 1781
Sir
Yours pr Capt Vanduson? have Recd. & Noted the contents - am Surprisd to hear that you have not recd. the Hollow Ware as it has been at Hartford in the Care of Ebenezer Barned Junr. more than a Month who had orders to Send it Immediately to you - If you have an Opprtunity I wish you to Send and order for for [sic] it as I wish you to have it as Soon as posable and Shall be Willing to do what is Reasonable on the Subject - Inclosd is an Order on strikethrough: unclear Mr. Hobby? for twenty dollars. as he has Effects of ours in his hands. I have orderd him to pay you ten Dollars More as Soon as he shall Receive'd It - which If insuficient for our part in Cash - you will informe us. I Shall this day write Mr. Bates on the Subject of Lumbrr. &c? - and know what quantity he is like to procure - we have Som Ship? damaged Bread which we Would Wish to turne in I wish to know what quantity you will Want which we Can Delivr at New London also shall Order Shot Agreable to the Memorandum of Capt. Vanduron to be left? at Edwd Hallam of N London

Chauncy Whittlecy Esqr
Middletown
Austin's Letter
Octr 1st 1789

New London Oct 09. 1781

Dear Sir,

                    Twice I attempted to come and Settle the Hunters [Accots?], the first time I carryd the [accot?] to Midddletown in order for Settlements, but was obliged to return immediately back on acct. of some unclear that was urgent; occasiond by the fire . the next time meeting W. Hallam on the Road of East Haddan, was obleged to return- as I am extremely anxious to have the [accot?] Instantly closed, being exceedingly in want of all the cash that may be due us, must beg the particular favour of you (as my Brother in Sick & it will be very inconvenient for me to leave home) - if you will assist my Brother George in adjusting the [accot?] with W unclear; shall most willingly make you and satisfaction for the time & trouble - our disagreable Situations at this place makes it more necessary to close all out [accot] - if any
1780 Middletown Nov 27th

To all people to whom these presents shall come, [Greetings?]. know ye that there's the general assembly of the Governor and company of the state of Connecticut holden at Hartford  by adjournment on the tenth day of January 1782 made [of?] passed the following resolve unclear unclear. As a general assembly of the governor and company of the state of Connecticut holden at Hartford by adjournment on the tenth day of January 1782. Upon the [solision?] of [Chauneey?] unclear of Middletown in the county of Hartford administrator on the confiscated estate of James [Jauneey?] of the city of New York unclear to this assembly that said [Jauneyy?] having large demands upon Joshua Chandler late of unclear New Haven now with the enemies of the united states. [said?] [Jauneey?] made a full settlement with said Chandler of all demands of that sundry. Notes given by Chandler to said [Jauneey?] to the amount of about 1500 [pounds?]- Lawful money in to the hands of Charles [chauncey?] of New Haven in New Haven county to deliver up to said Chandler upon said Chandler's conveying to said [Jauneey?] two pieces of land in the [Larish?] of Meridan and town of Wallingford lately belonging to Yale Bishop of Wallingford  being about eighty eight unclear. And also one other piece in said Wallingford containing about thirty unclear lately belonging to Benjamin [Bulver?] which pieces of land it was agreed between said [Jauneey?] [to?] chandler should be in full of said notes. And said Chandler on the 5th day of March [1779?] made and executed to said Charles [Chauneey?] his certain bond for the sum of 40,000 [pounds?] lawful money for the benefit of said [Jauneey?] conditioned that if said Chandler his heirs or assigns should be by a good authentic Deed convey to said [Chauneey?] his heirs and assigns three certain pieces of land in the township of Wallingford two pieces in the Parish of Meridan commonly called the Stone House, one piece containing eighty acres and the other about eight being the whole he bought Yale Bishop by a deed worded Lib-18th-Fol-69 unclear being had. Also the other of said peices which unclear in the old society being the homestead bought of Benjamin [Culver?] containing about thirty acres with all the buildings thereon which land bought of said [Culver?] is bounded and described in said deed worded lib-16th-fol-221 reference thereto being had which deed was to be with [coven?] and of warranty unclear said bond to be void as by said bond appears. which said bond never having been paid.

Sir. Please to pay Seventy Pounds Lawful Money to Mr. Samuel Gates unclear my Debt due from the Estate of James unclear of this receipt shall be your Discharge. New Haven unclear. Mr. Chauncey Whittlesey - unclear on James unclear Estate - Charles Chauncey

New York 26 Feby 1784
Dear Sir
I sent John Trumbull Esqr of Hartford sometime past a sum more than the amount of my note in your hands, for a certain purpose, the disposal of which will be determined the 6th of March next -- I will thank you to wait untill that time, I then call on Mr Trumbull, to whom I have given directions to pay the note, if he don't rise the money another way, if he does I will make provision to pay you -- At same time will thank you to be indulgent as you can in point of time -- The Winter has been so severe that we have done very little business -- I will settle the note in a fair & honorable manner, and pay you the full interest that may be due thereon -- I am
Dear Sir
Your Obedient Servant
Sam Broome

Mr Whittelsey
If you can think of any way by which I can win five Pounds for David's book in the way of Business I am content to you should charge me that [fun?]
May 29th [86?]

                                                               [signature unreadable]

New York September 29th 1787
Mr Chauncey Whittelsy
Dear Sir,
We have given your wines every chance ... market and am convinced that on a sale of the whole ... will not be able to get more than thirty five pounds ... Currency average miss? so much, In this case the Net ... to gather with the Balance of Rum & Sugar Sales will little ... ome if so much as the amount of monys already advanced by us -- Therefore your Note to Haydock & Bowne will in this ... remain unsatisfied. This if we remember was unclear ... if you have given them your positive promise of pays ... unt for this sum from the avails of goods left with us we ... will on having from you pay it them -- and hurt? if ... our power in the coun? of the approaching month ... y rate before November has expired -- we are? ... that any sacrifice should be made on the wines.  [best?]] hope ... you have made of those at W Town will fully come ... for any unclear that arises here -- We remain
Sirs unclear
NB The Rum has been delivered for Roounclear -- we have his Brothers Runclear -- you must if you see him take up the note -- NJ

Received New York June 23rd 1792 of [] Chauncey Whittelsey  by the [] of Timothy Hall Three box said to contain three hundred pistols being the property of the United States [] are to be delievered to the Order of the Secretary of War.
3 Boxes 300 Pistols                                                  For [  ]  Smith

                                                                                [Signature unreadable]

(q. q.)
This is to Certify, that Chancey [Chauncey] Whittelsey, of the Town of Middletown, in the County of Middletown, in the District of Connecticut, Esquire -- hath paid the duty of Two Dollars, upon a Two wheel Carriage, called a Sulkey, owned by him, having No top, on Wooden Springs, to be drawn by One Horse, for the conveyance of one person; for the year to end on the 30th of September 1798
Robert Marnoe
Collector of the revenue for the 5th of 6th division in the only survey in the District of Connecticut

District of New London 1799
I hereby acknowledge to have reiceived of Chauncey Whittelsey

                                  Collector of the Cuftoms for the diftrict of the fum of Three Hundered twenty seven dollars & fifty six cents being the amount of monies  collected by him for the fupport of the Marine Hospitals of the United States, from September 1, 1798 until 30 June 1799.

agreeably to a letter of advice from the Secretary of the Treafury, dated [    ] of October 1799 for which I have figned duplicate receipts.

       $327.56                                                                                                                             [] my for agent for marine Hospital 
                                                                                                                                                       New London
